posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked:
We have a problem with our LEDs. Half of the strip is stuttering. The strip is a couple of different strips which are soldered together.

The soldering is fine; we resoldered a couple of times, as well as replaced the strip.

They are connected to the roboRIO PWM , data, as well as voltage. We are using 22 AWG wire.

Does anyone have an idea of what is happening here?

posts.name: Ege Saygılı
posts.cooked:
We always had issues with long cable runs going to addressable LED matrixes on another project I have worked on not related to FRC , I am guessing the signal degrades somehow over long cable runs. Best advice I could give / easiest way to solve the issue is to run two seperate cables from the RoboRIO connected to the lower input of the strip, keeping cable runs minimal, and to see if that fixes it.

Edit: when we look at both SK6812 and WS2812 datasheets’ typical application circuits, both popular smart LED chips, we can see the power inputs are filtered but the data lines are just wired directly, it is safe to expect enough voltage drops to cause problems accross long wire runs on the data lines.

image 1226×466 68.5 KB

image 1226×466 68.5 KB

image 1226×466 68.5 KB

I agree with Crystolyte, I think there may be some sort of signal degradation. It could be an EMI(electromagnetic interference) issue. Does the LED data wire run near motor wires? You could try probing the data wire with an oscilloscope and see if the signal looks clean.

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked: Are you powering the separate segments independently, or is power run alongside the data wire? You want the data wire to stay close to, or be twisted together with the ground wire between segments.

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: They are twisted

Crystolyte:

Edit: when we look at both SK6812 and WS2812 datasheets’ typical application circuits, both popular smart LED chips, we can see the power inputs are filtered but the data lines are just wired directly, it is safe to expect enough voltage drops to cause problems accross long wire runs on the data lines.

The DO pin on that schematic is a digital output that will be powered by the smart LED itself, boosted to the filtered Vcc supply voltage by the chip. So I wouldn’t expect the data line to have any worse voltage sag than the supply voltage itself.

GalDotan:

They are connected to the roboRIO PWM , data, as well as voltage.

This is likely the problem. The Rio GPIO ports can only supply a small amount of power. I generally will not try to run more than a dozen or so LEDs powered directly off the GPIO pins. You will need to power the Vcc from a voltage regulator.

We often use the 2A side of a VRM to power short runs, and try to provide at least 1A @ 5V per linear foot of LED strip. For long runs like you have there, you should consider using a voltage regulator that can provide more power.

You are almost certainly browning out your LED strip. You can verify this by measuring the Vcc-GND voltage at the far end of the LED strip.

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: Not near and motors, I think we around 1.5 meter of cable over all

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: The voltage in the start lf the strip is 5.78 and in the end its 5.5 with all of the leds on full power

How many LEDs are in the total strip?

I count about 20 - 22 LEDs in each upright, plus a couple strips crossing between the two sides. Adafruit recommends allocating 60mA of power per LED, and the Rio GPIO ports are rated to push (IIRC) 600mA. So connecting directly to the Rio for power to the strip you will start to have problems past about 10 fully illuminated (bright white) pixels.

You are running blue and magenta, which will tend to use less power, but you’re still well beyond the length I would expect the Rio to be able to handle.

The 5.5V you are measuring is an average reading, and a DMM will typically not show you the dips. But even that amount of sag over the length of the strip is something of a red flag.

TL;DR: Your LED strips are too long to be powered directly off of the PWM port of the Rio. You need to use a stronger voltage regulator.

posts.name: Ege Saygılı
posts.cooked: You are right, rather than voltage drop the parasitic capacitance in the wire runs could also cause the problem with the data stream.

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: About 92 LEDs. Will the 5V 2A port be enough?

(92 LEDs) x (0.060 Amp/LED) = 5.52 Amps at full (bright white) illumination.

One color (red, green, or blue) will use about 1/3 of this. Magenta uses both red and blue, which would bring you to 2/3.

So a 2A regulator will do a lot better than the 0.6A you can get from the PWM port, but is still a bit under spec for powering the full strip.

In the past, we have used an automotive regulator like this one to provide clean power for our LED strips. You should probably look for something rated for at least 5A output.

EDIT: The regulator I linked is rated to work down to a 10V input voltage. In competition, the battery voltage can dip significantly below that, which could cause the LEDs to be erratic. Pay attention to the minimum input voltage rating. It might make sense to get a more expensive boost/buc converter which can tolerate more variability.

This is more critical for powering vision coprocessors and the like, where a brownout can kill your match. But it might also prevent your LEDs from going haywire.

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: I will try the VRM while I order a proper one. Can I connect the power in the middle of the strip? Do I need to connect the ground to both the VRM and RIO?

GalDotan:

Can I connect the power in the middle of the strip?

Anything labelled “Vcc” is connected together, so it technically doesn’t matter where on the strip you supply power. I would avoid providing power to one strip from more than one point on each segment, however.

For simplicity, I usually try to connect all wires to one end (the input end!) of each LED strip segment, and orient these so the connection is as low on the robot as possible - to keep wiring runs short and to hide them away from potential damage.

GalDotan:

Do I need to connect the ground to both the VRM and RIO?

I’ve omitted the GND connection to the PWM port and had everything “work,” but Adafruit recommends connecting GND to both your regulator and your PWM port, so I would do it that way. You are less likely to have noisy digital signals if you run the extra GND wire.

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: I will try end update. Thank you!

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
veg:

the 0.6A you can get from the PWM port

Where did you get that from? The roboRIO data sheet says the 6v power can source 2.2A, which is what the PWM ports use.

Joe_Ross:

The roboRIO data sheet says the 6v power can source 2.2A, which is what the PWM ports use.

I stand corrected. I was going by memory.

That number actually makes more sense given what we see in the video. 92 pixels at 1/3 power (blue only) would draw 1.84A. Turning on the red LEDs to make magenta will increase the draw to about twice that, 3.68A, which now exceeds the 2.2A maximum and browns out the LED strip.

The 2.2A is also shared with any other PWM or GPIO outputs, so the full amount may not be available for running pixels. But assuming you have that full amount available for LEDs, you’d want to avoid running more than about 36 pixels directly off the Rio Vcc.

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: Can I connect both the pwm power as well as the vrm to get 4.2A max?

I would not do this.

If there is any difference in output voltage between the two, they will fight each other, and Bad Things can happen.

Remember that any power going into your LEDs is not going into your motors, so be purposeful with your energy budget here.

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: Maybe I can split the strips into two. The data will be shared, but they will get power separately, one from the RIO and one from the VRM .
